title: Root Sports apologizes for on-air profanity as Astros celebrate first playoff berth in 10 years
text:
Photo: John VanBeekum, Houston Chronicle Image 1 of / 12 12 1979
The Astros entered the final weekend of the regular season trailing the first-place Reds by 2.5 games, but were eliminated after losing their series opener in Los Angeles. They blew a 5-1 lead in the eighth inning against the Dodgers. The Astros won their final two games to finish 1.5 games behind Cincinnati.
Photo: John VanBeekum, Houston Chronicle 1979
The Astros entered the final weekend of the regular season... Image 2 of 12 1980
The Astros held a three-game lead entering their final series at Los Angeles, but were swept in the three-game set by the Dodgers to force a one-game playoff for the NL West title. Joe Niekro tossed a six-hit complete game and struck out six in the 7-1 win that punched Houston's first playoff appearance.
Photo: Dave Bauman, AP 1980
The Astros held a three-game lead entering their final series... Image 3 of 12 1981
A week after Nolan Ryan no-hit the Dodgers at the Astrodome, the Astros finished the regular season in Los Angeles. Needing a win to clinch the second-half title during the strike-shortened season, they lost the first two games of the series. But the Reds also lost twice in Atlanta to put Houston in the playoffs.
Photo: TIM JOHNSON, AP 1981
A week after Nolan Ryan no-hit the Dodgers at the Astrodome,... Image 4 of 12 1986
The Astros actually sealed the NL West title with nine games to spare, and did it in dramatic fashion as Mike Scott (second from right) no-hit the Giants at the Astrodome to clinch the pennant.
Photo: Howard Castleberry, Houston Chronicle 1986
The Astros actually sealed the NL West title with nine games... Image 5 of 12 1997
In their regular-season home finale, the Astros clinched the first playoff berth of the Jeff Bagwell/Craig Biggio era. Mike Hampton tossed a four-hit complete game to beat the Cubs 9-1 for the NL Central title and put Houston in the postseason for the first time in 11 years.
Photo: SMILEY N. POOL, Houston Chronicle 1997
In their regular-season home finale, the Astros clinched the... Image 6 of 12 1999
In their final season at the Astrodome, the Astros went all the way to the final day against the Dodgers, with Mike Hampton working seven innings of one-run ball in a 9-4 clincher to take the NL Central.
Photo: Kerwin Plevka, Houston Chronicle 1999
In their final season at the Astrodome, the Astros went all... Image 7 of 12 2001
The NL Central race came down to a three-game series at St. Louis, with the Astros winning two of three to take the NL Central title. The Cardinals later claimed "co-champion" status because the teams finished tied with 93-69 records. But the Astros got the division champion's playoff seed because they won the head-to-head series.
Photo: SMILEY N. POOL, HOUSTON CHRONICLE 2001
The NL Central race came down to a three-game series at St.... Image 8 of 12 2003
The Astros went into the final weekend tied with the Cubs for first in the NL Central, but lost two of three in Milwaukee to fall out of the playoffs. That was part of a late-season collapse that saw Houston drop six of its final eight games.
Photo: SMILEY N. POOL, HOUSTON CHRONICLE 2003
The Astros went into the final weekend tied with the Cubs for... Image 9 of 12 2004
The Astros went 40-18 from the start of August until the end of the regular season. Brandon Backe tossed five strong innings and six relievers locked down the lead to clinch the NL wild card in a 5-3 win over the Rockies in the regular-season finale at Minute Maid Park.
Photo: Karen Warren, Houston Chronicle 2004
The Astros went 40-18 from the start of August until the end... Image 10 of 12 2005
After starting the season 15-30, the Astros once again had a strong second half. Things again went to the final day of the regular season, with a three-run rally in the sixth inning giving the Astros a 6-4 victory over the Cubs that clinched the NL wild card.
Photo: Karen Warren, HOUSTON CHRONICLE 2005
After starting the season 15-30, the Astros once again had a... Image 11 of 12 2006
The Astros' bid for three straight playoff berths fell short on the final weekend. The Astros went into Atlanta trailing by 1.5 games, but lost two of three to the Braves to fall shy of the postseason.
Photo: KAREN WARREN, Houston Chronicle 2006
The Astros' bid for three straight playoff berths fell short... Image 12 of 12 Root Sports apologizes for on-air profanity as Astros celebrate first playoff berth in 10 years 1 / 12 Back to Gallery Root Sports Southwest apologized Sunday to viewers for on-air profanities used by the Astros during live coverage of the team's post-game celebration after clinching a berth in the American League wild card game.
The language took place as Astros manager A.J. Hinch spoke to players about 30 minutes into the clubhouse celebration.
"We got together in February and we talked about bringing our best every night. Nobody outside this clubhouse thought we had a chance and now look at us," Hinch said to players.
"Bleep 'em," said one player who was out of range of the network camera, which was stationed behind Hinch.
"They can say a lot of things about this team, right, but one thing they're going to say forever is we're a bleeping playoff team," Hinch continued. "We'll have to earn a home game, and it will take a few more wins, but I'll bet on this team. I love you (censored)."
A few minutes after the comments, Root Southwest studio host Bart Enis said, "We want to apologize to all of you for some of the language you heard in the clubhouse during the celebration. We know a lot of you were watching and we're seeing some of it on Twitter. You know, you go into the clubhouse with a live camera, that's just the way it goes."
